title: Sylvia McNair
text:
Sylvia McNair (born June 23, 1956) is an American <a href="opera">opera</a> singer and <a href="classical%20music">classical</a> recitalist who has also achieved notable success in the <a href="Broadway%20theatre">Broadway</a> and <a href="cabaret">cabaret</a> genres. McNair, a <a href="soprano">soprano</a>, has made several critically acclaimed recordings and has won two <a href="Grammy%20Award">Grammy Award</a>s.
Early life and musical training.
Sylvia McNair was born in <a href="Mansfield%2C%20Ohio">Mansfield, Ohio</a>, the daughter of George and Marilou McNair. As a youth, she studied <a href="violin">violin</a>. She originally enrolled in the undergraduate music program at <a href="Wheaton%20College%20%28Illinois%29">Wheaton (Ill.) College</a> as a violin major, but was encouraged by a violin instructor there to study voice as well. She commenced vocal studies at Wheaton with Margarita Evans, and finding herself more suited to singing, discontinued violin as her major. She earned a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Music">Bachelor of Music</a> degree in 1978 from Wheaton and subsequently a <a href="Master%20of%20Music">Master of Music</a> with Distinction in 1983 from <a href="Indiana%20University">Indiana University</a> (whose music school is now the <a href="Jacobs%20School%20of%20Music">Jacobs School of Music</a>), where she studied voice with <a href="Virginia%20MacWatters">Virginia MacWatters</a>, John Wustman, and <a href="Virginia%20Zeani">Virginia Zeani</a>.
Career.
McNair made her professional concert debut in 1980 with the <a href="Indianapolis%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra</a>. Her operatic debut, in 1982, was as Sandrina in <a href="Joseph%20Haydn">Haydn</a>'s "L'infedeltà delusa" with the <a href="Mostly%20Mozart">Mostly Mozart</a> Festival. She appeared regularly at the <a href="Vienna%20State%20Opera">Vienna State Opera</a>, the <a href="Salzburg%20Festival">Salzburg Festival</a>, <a href="Royal%20Opera%20House">Royal Opera House</a> at <a href="Covent%20Garden">Covent Garden</a>, the <a href="Santa%20Fe%20Opera">Santa Fe Opera</a>, the <a href="San%20Francisco%20Opera">San Francisco Opera</a>, and at the <a href="Metropolitan%20Opera">Metropolitan Opera</a>, and has soloed with many major European and American orchestras.
Since the late 1990s, McNair has changed the focus of her singing career to <a href="Broadway%20theatre">Broadway</a> and <a href="jazz">jazz</a> styles. In these genres she has achieved considerable critical acclaim and commercial success.
From 2006 to 2017, McNair was part of the voice faculty of the Jacobs School of Music at Indiana University, her <a href="alma%20mater">alma mater</a>. She taught English diction (IPA), opera workshop, and has taught private lessons to a few female singers and a tenor.
From 2012 to 2017, McNair has served as a judge and mentor for the Songbook Academy, a summer intensive for high school students operated by the <a href="Great%20American%20Songbook%20Foundation">Great American Songbook Foundation</a> and founded by <a href="Michael%20Feinstein">Michael Feinstein</a>.
She has also written many children books about countries and the U.S.A.
Critical commentary.
"Her <a href="Musical%20phrasing">phrasing</a> is exemplary. Her modulations are inspired. Her time is enviable. . . . I could get used to this kind of ecstasy." —<a href="Rex%20Reed">Rex Reed</a>, 2005
Personal.
McNair married <a href="Conducting">conductor</a> <a href="Hal%20France">Hal France</a> in 1986. The couple are now divorced.
She was diagnosed with <a href="breast%20cancer">breast cancer</a> in 2006. Her treatments have included <a href="mastectomy">mastectomy</a>, <a href="chemotherapy">chemotherapy</a> and <a href="radiation%20therapy">radiation therapy</a>.
In December 2017, McNair came forward as one of several women accusing famed conductor <a href="Charles%20Dutoit">Charles Dutoit</a> of sexual assault. McNair said that Dutoit "tried to have his way" with her after a March 1985 rehearsal with the <a href="Minnesota%20Orchestra">Minnesota Orchestra</a>.
Recorded repertoire.
Sylvia McNair has made over 70 recordings, including many complete operas (including Ilia in <a href="Mozart">Mozart</a>'s "<a href="Idomeneo%2C%20re%20di%20Creta">Idomeneo, re di Creta</a>", Poppea in <a href="Monteverdi">Monteverdi</a>'s "<a href="L%27incoronazione%20di%20Poppea">L'incoronazione di Poppea</a>", both under the direction of Sir <a href="John%20Eliot%20Gardiner">John Eliot Gardiner</a> with the <a href="English%20Baroque%20Soloists">English Baroque Soloists</a> for the ARCHIV label), and <a href="Samuel%20Barber">Samuel Barber</a>'s "Knoxville Summer of 1915". She has also recorded a number of recitals, ranging from "<a href="Mozart">Mozart</a> arias" with <a href="Sir%20Neville%20Marriner">Sir Neville Marriner</a> and the <a href="Academy%20of%20St%20Martin-in-the-Fields">Academy of St Martin-in-the-Fields</a> to CDs with <a href="Andr%C3%A9%20Previn">André Previn</a> of music by <a href="Jerome%20Kern">Jerome Kern</a> and <a href="Harold%20Arlen">Harold Arlen</a> ("Sure Thing" and "Come Rain or Come Shine"). The Previn collaboration also yielded a CD of Andre's works called "From Ordinary Things", including: "Four Songs" and "Two Remembrances" with lyrics by <a href="Toni%20Morrison">Toni Morrison</a>, "Vocalise" with Cellist <a href="Yo%20Yo%20Ma">Yo Yo Ma</a>, and well as the "Cello Sonata", again with <a href="Yo%20Yo%20Ma">Yo Yo Ma</a> and the composer at the piano throughout.
